title: 105_s494
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" and includes provisions for prisoner copayments for health care services. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" amends Chapter 303 of title 18, United States Code, by adding a section on prisoner copayments for health care services. It defines terms like account, Director, health care provider, health care visit, and prisoner. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" defines terms related to prisoner copayments for health care services, including qualified health care visits during incarceration, excluding certain types of visits. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons assesses and collects copayments for health care services, including a fee of $3 to $5 for each qualified health care visit and up to $5 for prescription medication. Prisoners under 18, pregnant, mentally ill, or disabled are exempt from copayments. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons assesses and collects copayments for health care services, including fees for prescription medication and health care visits resulting from injuries inflicted by another prisoner. The fees are collected from the prisoner receiving the services or the prisoner responsible for the injury. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons collects fees for health care services from prisoners, either at the time of the visit or through an installment plan if the account balance is insufficient. Treatment cannot be refused based on financial reasons, and collected amounts are used by the Director. The Director of the Bureau of Prisons collects fees for health care services from prisoners, which are deposited into the Crime Victims' Fund. The Director is required to submit annual reports to Congress on the amounts collected and the impact on prisoners' health care visits. Prisoners are required to pay copayments for health care services.
